best_practices: Prioritize comprehensive API coverage over specialized workflow tools
Use clear, action-oriented tool names with service prefixes (e.g., 'github_create_issue')
Support both JSON and Markdown response formats for flexibility
Implement pagination with limit/offset and has_more indicators
Provide actionable error messages that guide AI agents toward solutions
Use Zod (TypeScript) or Pydantic (Python) for input validation
Extract common functionality into reusable helper functions
Include comprehensive tool descriptions with input/output schemas
Set appropriate tool annotations (readOnlyHint, destructiveHint, etc.)
Create evaluations with complex, realistic questions to test server quality
anti_patterns: Creating tools without service prefixes (causes naming conflicts)
Returning unformatted data without JSON/Markdown options
Loading all results into memory instead of implementing pagination
Generic error messages that don't help agents recover
Duplicating code across tools instead of using shared utilities
Missing input validation or constraints on parameters
Tool descriptions that don't explain when to use the tool
Evaluation questions that depend on current state or other questions
Synchronous I/O operations instead of async/await patterns

faq.question: Should I create one tool per API endpoint or workflow-oriented tools?
faq.answer: Prioritize comprehensive API coverage with one tool per endpoint. This gives AI agents flexibility to compose operations. Workflow tools can be added for convenience, but comprehensive coverage is the foundation.

faq.question: Which language should I use - Python or TypeScript?
faq.answer: TypeScript is recommended for best SDK support, compatibility with execution environments like MCPB, and AI model proficiency. Python is also well-supported via FastMCP if you prefer it.

faq.question: What transport should I use - stdio or streamable HTTP?
faq.answer: Use streamable HTTP for remote servers and multi-client scenarios (stateless JSON is simpler to scale). Use stdio for local integrations and command-line tools.

faq.question: How do I create good evaluation questions?
faq.answer: Create complex, realistic questions that: (1) require multiple tool calls, (2) use only read-only operations, (3) are independent of other questions, (4) have stable answers that won't change over time, (5) can be verified by string comparison, and (6) reflect real human use cases.

faq.question: What makes a high-quality MCP server?
faq.answer: Quality is measured by how well LLMs can accomplish real-world tasks using your tools. Focus on: clear tool naming, comprehensive descriptions, proper pagination, actionable error messages, and passing rigorous evaluations.

faq.question: How do I handle large result sets?
faq.answer: Implement pagination with limit/offset parameters, return has_more and next_offset indicators, and consider a CHARACTER_LIMIT constant to truncate responses with clear messages when needed.

faq.question: What are tool annotations and why do they matter?
faq.answer: Annotations like readOnlyHint, destructiveHint, idempotentHint, and openWorldHint help clients understand tool behavior. They're hints, not security guarantees, but help AI agents use tools appropriately.
